job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
cons:
Students are learning nothing by experiencing negative influence of CEO and staff. Externship and employment placement are fake just to maintain the school accreditation as they are doing now for 2019 accreditation. I don't know why this school has not being audited by the California Department of Public Health and Federal Department of Education. 
The CEO yells at everyone. There's not communication and coordination. 
Some instructors and students are concerned about expired tools for venipuncture and other procedures. There's high risk of blood-borne disease but they don't care.
Their mission is to help low-income students. In fact, they exploit and humiliate low-income students. It's a fraud.

The company is a complete mess from top to bottom. 

There is no HR, and trust me, a company like BAMA drastically needs HR. 

The technology that the staff uses is very dated and is not adequate for the volume of people that the company is servicing forcing the staff to work/ track our work manually and on google sheets.  Which was a total headache for everyone involved.

The CEO, herself,  is an absolutely terrible human. 
When it comes to actual change, innovation and restructuring for the better, she will intensely push back. 
There are no tiers of upper management so you have direct access and communication with the CEO at all moments. There are no formalities when staff members need to be "reprimanded" about their behavior(s). More on that below. 

Now, having close proximity to the CEO wouldn't be such a huge issue if the CEO was someone who carried courtesy, respect for others, and common sense; she does not. 

The CEO is an angry and unstable person. 
She will micromanage you and nitpick you for doing something "wrong" or not exactly how she wanted it to be executed (when often she doesn't even explain to you on how she wants/needs it to be done).  And If you have grown to be someone she doesn't like--she will scream at you and publicly humiliate you in front of students, other staff members; it doesn't matter who it is. She has no respect for her workers in the matter that she speaks to them when she is angry and feels the need to degrades\ them. Some days, she will come into the office in a good mood and other times, she will not in a good mood and she may go off on you-- for no reason at all. None of this is appropriate or professional behavior for upper management and it should not be tolerated on any premises. But, interestingly, that is the culture at BAMA. Staff members have turned a blind eye to it or have just altogether accepted the CEO's behavior. The CEO has made some staff members cry on multiple occasion and other former employees have left their position precisely because the CEO's terrible conduct. 

The CEO has no integrity, and her moves are according to numbers and ratings. If she's meeting her number of enrollments and there are no bad reviews on Yelp, she is satisfied for the moment. The CEO does not care about her team's growth or well-being and she does not genuinely care about students' endeavors in the medical field. 

If you are seeking jobs, keep looking elsewhere.
